titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Wednesday.

I rose this morning, with a full determination to employ industriously the day, but accomplished nothing more than to write two short answers to Letters, and to begin the attempt to redeem the arrears of my diary from the 24th. of March when I was compelled to stop it— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I am still reading W. L Stone’s Letters upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry— And read this afternoon most of Mitchell’s Translation of the Wasps of Aristophanes— These plays have opened to me a field of the drama, nearly new— I had before an imperfect idea of the old Greek Comedy— I find the Anapaestic measure of Mitchell’s Translation grows tedious in its long continuance— The day was showery and I lost again the opportunity of exercise by walking— Alpheus Spear came and settled for Rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to the 1st. of July. Question about the parish taxes—left unadjusted— Paid an Evening visit to my neighbour George W. Beale— I had something of a Rhumatic Head-ache
2 V:15. Thursday.

This day was absorbed almost entirely by visitors— Dr Phelps and Mr Odiorne are Anti-Masons— They came to enquire if I would go as a delegate to the Anti-masonic Convention to be held the first week in September at Worcester, to nominate a Candidate for Governor and a ticket for Electors of President and Vice President— I declined. They then asked if I would attend the Convention as a Spectator, which I also declined, for reasons which I gave them. chiefly, to avoid all interference with the Presidential election now approaching— Mr Proudfit is Minister of the Presbyterian Church at Newbury Port, and brought me a Letter of introduction from Dr Codman, of Dorchester— He mentioned the sudden death of a waiter at the Hingham Hotel the Night before last— Mr Everett and Mr Davis paid a long afternoon visit— Dr Parkman a short one— The Cholera still rages at New-York though with some abatement. It is spreading to Philadelphia, and was in Pokeepsie when I was there— A case of it occurred this day on board a vessel quarantined in Boston Harbour— Evening walk with the Ladies.
3. V. Friday.

Morning Thunder Showers— I finished reading W. L. Stones Letters on Masonry and Anti-masonry, which are addressed to me— I have many reflections to make upon them, for future consideration— This day was undisturbed by visitors, yet all that I did was to finish a Letter I had begun yesterday to R. Rush— I have had these three days a dull rhumatic head-ache which I slept off this afternoon by a three hours Siesta.— Finished reading Mitchell’s Translation of the Wasps of Aristophanes, and read the Preface to Gifford’s Translation of the Satires of Persius— The Ladies rode out this afternoon, and I paid an evening visit at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— Visited also my Nursery of young trees— Almost all those which came up from the seed nut or stone, were killed by the winter down to the surface of the ground. New shoots have sprung up this Summer, which will be liable to be killed next Winter in the same manner— A very essential protection for trees in a Nursery is shade— And another essential is the art of trimming. I have served an apprenticeship of six years to the trade of raising trees from the seed, and have just learnt that I know nothing about it.
4. V. Saturday.

Charles and his wife went in to Boston and returned to dinner. John Kirk also went in— My day was in a great measure wasted. I read the Appendix to Stone’s Letters upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry in which I remarked the extraordinary difference between the Obligation of the Master’s degree as it was in 1730. and as it is now— The Oath then was only never to reveal the Secrets—but the penalty was nearly the same as now.— My reflections on this Subject, bring me to no results— But I began upon something else— Many Circumstances at the present time admonish me to be in a state of preparation for the approaching close of my life, and particularly to dispose of my worldly affairs by Will— I began this day to make a Schedule or Inventory of my property and of my debts— The last Will that I made was in 1819. since which the State of my property and the condition of my family have totally changed— I wrote one short Letter and part of another— About 6 in the afternoon I bathed with Charles at Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, and swam from wharf to wharf—
5. V.15. Sunday.

Communion day. Mr Whitney preached in the forenoon from 9 Timothy 3.16. “And without controversy great is the mystery of Godliness: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of Angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory”— He undertook to extract from this text an Unitarian Commentary— My wife at her own proposal took the Communion with us, as a member of another, the Episcopalian Church— In the afternoon, Mr. Whitney’s text was from Luke 16:8: “For the children of this world are in their generation wiser than the children of light.” After the Sermon, he read from a Newspaper the Proclamation of the Governor, appointing next Thursday as a day of fasting, humiliation and prayer; on account of the pestilential disease, the Cholera—raging, at New-York and in several other places, and from which we may not hope to be exempted. Mr Whitney announced that there would be but one Service to begin at 10 in the Morning— Sultry day and showery Evening. Louisa C. Smith dined with us— I began writing upon Masonry, and read the second Sermon of Saurin, upon delays of conversion.
6. V:30 Monday

Mr Brooks and Mr Frothingham paid us a morning visit. Charles went into Boston, and did not return till Evening— The after part of the day was showery with continued thunder and Lightening— Mrs Adams was quite unwell, and kept her chamber great part of the day— I wasted much time in searching for keys of my Chests, and for plans, and how the rest of the day wore out, I cannot tell— The morning was gone before I was aware of it— In the afternoon I made some further progress in the Schedule of property to be disposed of by Will, and found occasion to inquire at the probate Office in Dedham for documents, and at the Registry of Deeds, for a Deed which I left there on the 7th of December to be recorded. I undertook also to number the Deeds and plans with references to each other and to both in the Schedule— These are precautions necessary to be taken in the disposal of an Estate dispersed in so many places as mine, and encumbered with so many heavy debts and obligations— Would I could be effectively impressed with my own duty to simplify them while the power to do it is left me.
7. V. Tuesday.

Showery day, with distant thunder and lightening, and sultry weather— Mrs Adams was confined to her chamber— My Chief occupations were, remarks upon Stone’s Letters to me, on Masonry and Anti-masonry, a subject upon which my own reflections greatly need arrangement, and upon which I am fearful of consuming too much time—and upon the Schedule of my debts and Estate to be devised— Desultory reading of Southey’s political Essays, republished in two Volumes of which Dr G. Parkman has sent me out the first— They are like the withered flowers of a hortus siccus— Like stale Champaign Wine— Like an almanack of a year long gone by—like an old Letter of my own writing— Like any thing that once was fresh and lively, and brisk and now is obsolete flat and unprofitable. He republishes them as if they were the vaticinations of Cassandra— In the evening I read two or three Sections of a Dissertation by Sir James Mackintosh, upon the progress of ethical Science within the last two Centuries—a Work of great learning and ingenuity— That excellent and illustrious man died on the 6th. of June last, and Jeremy Bentham the next day.
8. V:15 Wednesday.

In a half lucid interval of weather, between ten and eleven this Morning, I went with Charles and bathed at Greenleaf’s wharf. I swam from wharf to wharf, and this was almost all my exercise for three days— The remainder of this day and evening was showery. I wrote further observations on Stone’s Letters on Masonry and Anti-masonry, and am getting bewildered with the Subject. It enlarges upon me as I proceed— The field becomes too wide. I want to concentrate and to point, and fear I am wasting my time. I proceeded also with my Schedule till I found myself arrested by missing papers which I have mislaid— Read further in Southey’s political Essays, and from their exceeding flatness now, wonder that they should ever have been read with pleasure. Very different is the impression with which I read Sir James Mackintosh’s Dissertation upon the progress of Ethical Science in the last two Centuries. I was much pleased with the Section upon the Ethics of the Middle Ages.
9. V. Thursday— Fast day for the Cholera.

Rain almost incessant the whole day— My wife and Charles’s attempted to go to Meeting in the Open Carriole, but before reaching the Meeting House were so drenched with rain that they were compelled to come back. Charles who was walking with me also returned. I proceeded, and heard Mr Whitney from Job 26.14. “Lo, these are parts of his ways; but how little a portion is heard of him?”— The drift of Mr Whitneys discourse was to argue that no inference against the benevolence of God, was to be drawn from the existence of this dreadful distemper— This is certain— Man is born to die, and there is not more of suffering in this than in many other of the forms of death. It is perhaps presumptuous to enquire, what are the purposes of the creator in the dispensation of Calamities— It is certain they are past finding out— If an inference in this case may be drawn from effects, one purpose is a judgment upon intemperance, a vice so prevailing and so destructive that it may need the interposition of Heaven to give it an effective check— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and spent the day with us— I wrote upon Anti-Masonry and read the third and last Sermon of Saurin upon delays of conversion or death-bed repentances— Good Sermons.
10. V. Friday

Rainy morning. Showery day— Sultry Evening. Mr Audubon, son of the ornithologist of that name was here this morning, and delivered me a Letter of introduction from General Jesup, written the day that I left Washington— Mr Audubon is going into the State of Maine, and perhaps into the adjoining Provinces in pursuit of birds for the completion of his great work, and his Son asked me for Letters of introduction for him to persons in Maine which I promised to send him to Boston to-morrow Morning— He wished also to obtain subscribers for his book, but its cost will be 800 dollars— It is published in London in Numbers at two guineas a number— I wrote Letters in the Evening for Mr Audubon, to J. Holmes, P. Sprague and B. Vaughan— This afternoon I rode round by the Farms road and across to Milton returning by the Railway house, with the Ladies and John’s Louisa— Bathed with Charles at Noon and swam from wharf to wharf— Read a few pages of Sir James Mackintosh’s Dissertation, and wrote upon Stone’s Letters— Althaea’s first flowering, a month later than usual.
11. V. Saturday.

Charles went into Boston and returned to dine— I sent by him the introductory Letters for Mr Audubon— Mr Oakman is a Revolutionary Soldier for whom I presented last Winter to the House of Representatives a petition to obtain a pension— A bill passed the House including his name, but was superseded in the Senate by the General Bill. I gave him a copy of that Act, and of the Directions from the War Department, to applicants for pensions— He belongs to Marshfield, and said he should go next Monday to Plymouth, to apply to the judge of Probate for his certificate— He told me that Mr Webster had purchased two farms at Marshfield— I bathed and swam from wharf to wharf before dinner— I find this exercise grows fatiguing— I wrote upon Masonry—upon my Schedule and a Letter to my Son John, directing him to send me, the Books which have been more than three years packed up at Washington— Sowed Lime-tree seeds and Mazzard Cherries in brown Earthen flower-pot; and took up the pot in the Nursery with the Strawberry-vines from the seed: they have not spread this Summer. Mr Beale spent the Evening here.
12. V. Sunday.

Our preacher this day was the Revd. Lemuel Capen, of Hawes’s place-Church South Boston, a graduate at Cambridge of 1810. His morning text was from Philippians 3.13. “Brethren I count not myself to have apprehended.” The doctrine, that all approaches to perfection are gradual—exemplified in the life and death of Christ— In the afternoon the text was from 2. Corinthians 7.10. “ For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.” Louisa Smith and Elizabeth Adams dined with us and were here again in the Evening with Mr and Mrs Edward Miller— I answered a Letter from Zacheus Bartlett of Plymouth—and Read the fourth Sermon of Saurin, an admirable, but very singular Discourse, upon the depth of the divine judgments— O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom, and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! The introduction is very beautiful— Dr Stevenson was here, going to Plymouth.
13. IV:45. Monday— Lumbago.

I am afflicted again with the Lumbago, of which I suffered much in the Months of May and June— Charles passed the day at Boston, and returned at eve— I spent the Morning in writing upon Free Masonry; but am as yet only wasting Ammunition— The abolition of that Order I believe to be necessary; and I feel a moral obligation to contribute as much as may be in my power to the event— It is a moral ulcer in the Community; but to heal it requires a tender as well as a skilful hand. I would wish to write and speak on the subject with effect— To that end it must be presented under new views—and with a concentration of aim— I am distrustful of my powers, and totally dissatisfied with what I have written— I am resolved to publish nothing, till the ensuing Presidential election shall be past— I rode with the Ladies and Children this afternoon, and called to see Solomon Thayer’s new Wheat— He has raised about forty bushels upon half an Acre. Gave me a slice of the bread— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and his daughter were here in the Evening— Charles’s Child is one year old.
14. IV:30. Tuesday.

Suffering still, though less than yesterday with the Lumbago— Coll Perkins and Mr Otis paid me a morning visit— These gentlemen have been alienated from me now, for about four years— The Events of the last Session of Congress have turned their dispositions to a spirit of conciliation which I have met with cordiality— Permanent enmities are not congenial either to my reason or my feelings— Augustus Whitney called this afternoon with a subscription paper for a carpet in the aisles of the Meeting house— He told me there were about fifty applicants for revolutionary pensions, at the probate Court this day— Charles went to Boston and returned not till Evening— The Ladies took tea at the House of my deceased brother’s widow— Elizabeth is the only one of her children remaining with her— Louisa C. Smith and J. M. Gourgas board there— I continue to waste time on Masonry—and also upon the Schedule of my debts and property—
15. IV.45. Wednesday.

Charles and his wife, with their infant daughter and her Nurse, Mrs Field, left us this Morning to go and spend a week, perhaps more with Mr P. C. Brooks at Medford— My writing upon Masonry absorbs at least six hours of each day, and as yet to my entire dissatisfaction— All my thoughts upon the subject are vagarious, and my efforts to bring them to a point fail. What is worse they keep me from really useful occupation. Mr Blake was here this afternoon, returning from a visit of a week to Mr Webster at his new residence at Marshfield— The place originally of Nathaniel Ray Thomas— Mrs Nowlan went to Boston to make Confession, and be prepared for what may happen— The Cholera seems to be abating in New-York, but is more fatal at Philadelphia, where all were so healthy when I was there, a little Month since— I took an hour’s ride this afternoon with my wife and John’s Louisa— Read scraps in Madame de Sevigné’s Letters. Sir James Mackintosh’s Dissertation upon Ethics, and Massinger’s very Woman— Weather sultry and oppressive— Planted a few Acorns of 1831. after soaking them in water till they sank.
16. IV:45. Thursday.

Heavy Thunder. Lightening and Shower in the Night— Cloudy day but without subsequent rain— Charles unexpectedly came out to dinner, his wife being on a party with Mr Brooks’s family at Nahant— I was still poring all the morning over Stone’s Letters and the afternoon in searching books and papers to answer a Letter which I received yesterday from William Jay—second Son of the late John Jay— Visited my Garden and pruned a number of my seedling trees— The severity of the last winter killed most of those which had come up the Spring and Summer before, to the surface of the ground, but six of the pear shoot buds and two of the Apples succeeded— The willow twigs, which I thrust into the Earth three weeks ago, are putting out many shoots— Kirk took into Boston one Carriole and brought out another in which I took a short ride with Charles— My lumbago is still troublesome, but less painful than it was.
17. V. Friday.

Rainy Night and Morning, and cold cloudy day. Charles went to Boston, and Louisa C. Smith came to pass some days with Mrs Adams. I concluded my desultory remarks upon Stone’s Letters on Masonry and Anti-Masonry, and find I have written 32 close quarto pages fit only for the husband of Venus— In the afternoon I continued the Schedule of my debts, Estates and incumbrances, with a view to making a Will—read in the Evening a few pages of Sir James Mackintosh’s Dissertation upon the History of Ethics— Coll. Quincy and his wife were here, to ask Charles’s wife to meet Miss Parker Edmund Quincy’s future bride— I visited my Nursery, and found my Liquid amber yet alive— Pruned several more of my fruit-trees— Two cases of malignant cholera occurred the day before yesterday in Boston—both women, who died within fifteen hours after being taken.
18. V. Saturday.

Morning visit from Mr and Mrs Lee. They are now lodging at the Norfolk house, but are going (flying from the Cholera) next week to Lancaster. In the afternoon Commodore and Mrs Morris came and took tea with us— The Commodore’s now Commander of the Navy-Yard at Charlestown but is going to Washington to take Patterson’s place as Commissioner of the Navy-Board— Mr Quincy President of the University was also here, and spoke again of Ward N. Boylston— Mrs Pitts was taken ill this day—much alarmed lest it should prove an Attack of Cholera— Dr Woodward came and assured us it was not— I finished a Letter, which I had begun yesterday, to W. L. Stone. Received one from A. H. Everett to which I began an answer.— My visitors abridged my afternoon writing, and also disappointed me a visit I had proposed to make to Mr Bailey— Read three Letters of Madame de Sevigne—always amusing. Account of the proposed Marriage of the Duke de Lauzun and Mademoiselle de Montpensier, and of its being broken off by Louis 14— Tax-bill.
19. V.15. Sunday.

Rainy Morning. Heard Mr George Whitney from Acts 10.34. “God is no respecter of persons.” And in the afternoon from Lamentations—“It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his Youth.”— Singular and sudden change of weather from Sultry S.W. wind to chilling N.E. Settlement of damp vapour on the windows in the house— I read the 5th. Sermon of Saurin—on the fast at the opening of the Campaign of the year 1706— The text is from Micah 6.1.2.3—and the preacher enumerates the complaints of the People against God, and those of God against the People. Mrs Pitts continued to be quite sick the whole of this day and Elizabeth Kirk was taken with Qualms this afternoon— Dr Woodward was here twice—and if Panic can give the Cholera, we shall all have it— My wife had read an account of this disease, as it prevails at Pondichery—In the Travels of Le Gentil Vol. 2. pwe found it in the book
20. V.15. Monday.

Morning visit from Dr Gray of Roxbury Mrs Pitts is convalescent; but Kirk’s child Elizabeth is threatened with a bilious fever— Wrote a short Letter to Dr Waterhouse, and wasted the remainder of the Morning in packing and directing Congressional Documents, of which I now receive a number by the mail almost every day— After dinner I visited my garden and Nursery, but was soon driven back by the heat of the Sun. I began writing the draught of my Will— Evening call at Mr Miller’s where I found Mr Beale, and Mr Gourgas—and afterwards at Mrs Adams’s my brother’s widow— She is yet much afflicted and uncertain what to do— Mr Miller urges her to decide whether she will take the house where she lives till next April or not— I offered her mine for the winter—and told her it was my intention that she should enjoy during life the net income of both the farms mortgaged to me by my brother, and that the Estates should after her decease, be divided equally among her children— They are all provided for, and absent, except Elizabeth, who boards with her as well as Mr Gourgas and Louisa C. Adams— Read Sir James Mackintosh on Ethics
21. IV:30. Tuesday.

Mrs Pitts continues recovering. Elizabeth Kirk still very sick— All these complaints partake of the nature of the pestilential epidemick which is summoning this people to consideration— I answered a Letter from Charles J. Ingersoll, wrote a short one to Commodore Rodgers, enclosing one for Joseph H. Adams from his Mother— After dinner I rode with Kirk to Dorchester and saw Mr John Bailey. Sent Kirk back— Conversed with Mr Bailey, on the subject of a Coalition between the Anti-Masons and the National Republicans, proposed by A. H. Everett. Returning home walking I met Mr Appleton and a young Man named Arvidsen, from Sweden—descended from acquaintances of mine of 50 years standing— They had been to visit me while I was from home— Mr Shepherd and Isaac P. Davis had also been here. I met the Carriage, with Mrs Adams and Louisa Smith. opposite Mrs Foy’s house that was—one mile South of Milton Bridge, and rode thence home.
22. IV. Wednesday— Lamplight.

I went into Boston in the Carriage for Charles’s wife and child; but the child has the meazles and they cannot come— I found Charles at Cunningham’s Auction room—where they were selling my brother’s Books— I purchased a considerable number of them— They all sold very low— There were several of mine among them— I called upon Lord and delivered to him the Manuscript of Dermott which he will submit to the inspection of Mr Pierpont— At Charles’s Office, and he was gone. Visit to H. G. Otis, he was out. Twice at A. H. Everett’s— Saw Mrs Everett at James H. Foster’s—found them at dinner— Coming out of town I met A. H. Everett, and promised to call upon him to-morrow. Returned to Quincy to dine—at half past three— Garden and Nursery after dinner. planted & soaked pignuts of 1831. Gathered white Currants to plant experimentally— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us. T. and Daniel Greenleaf Evening here with their Ladies.
23. IV:15. Friday Thursday.

I went again to Boston alone in the Carriage and took with me the first Volume of Madame de Sevigne’s Letters which beguiled the time. Saw Charles at his Office— He thinks he and his wife and Child may come to Quincy on Saturday— They are not sure the child has the meazles— Saw Mr Fuller at his Office— Conversation— Anti-Masonic— He expects to go to Worcester. At noon I called on Alexander H. Everett— Conversation with him— His proposition was that the Anti Masons should make no nomination at Worcester, but that in consideration that the National Republicans in New-York and Pennsylvania have agreed to adopt the Antimasonic tickets for Governor and Electors, so the Anti-masons here should adopt the National Republican Tickets for Governor and Electors, and make no nomination at Worcester— I said possibly the Anti-Masons might compound, and take the National Republican ticket for Governor if the Nationals would take their Electors— No— This was inadmissible— I came home to dine— Alexander Townsend here Three hours till Eve— Miss Otis and Ann Beale
24. IV:45. Friday.— Bath— Thunder-gust

lg.l: But see there, the radiant bow
And insensibly blend with each other
And each halts at the side of his brother

div.p: This morning I bathed and swam half-way from wharf to wharf returning home through Mr D. Greenleaf’s pasture. found a White Beech bearing fruit. Michaux. 3.18. and a Tupelo. p 36. I cut off a button wood straight stem in the road and planted it in the garden— The red Oak bears a very few Acorns, yet only half-formed— The Oaks have their leaves singed as with a blast, almost universally— There have come up Red Oaks from the Acorns that I planted in the Garden Nursery last Summer— This afternoon while the ladies were out riding there was a very heavy thundergust— I finished my second Letter to W. L. Stone, and it absorbed almost the whole day— Read a few pages of Sir James Mackintosh’s History of Ethics.
25. IV:30. Saturday.

I had proposed to bathe again this Morning; but a Northwester had brought on weather too cold— I wrote a Letter to Fisher, A. Kingsbury, declining the appointment of a delegate from the Norfolk County Anti-Masonic Convention to the general State Anti-Masonic Convention to be held at Worcester on the 5th. of September next— Letter also to Dr Waterhouse, and to Mrs Tudor— My Nephew and namesake was here before dinner—and Mr and Mrs Angier after dinner— Vacation at the Medford School next week, for Commencement— Mr Bailey was here before him and I told him the result of my conference with A. H. Everett, without naming him— President Quincy called this afternoon— He has not the Mortgage of my house in Hancock Street, and Tenements in Nassau Street executed in 1829; but thinks his Son may have it— Gave me a Card of invitation to Commencement. Charles, and his wife and Child, with Mrs Field, came back from their visit of ten days to Mr Brooks at Medford.
26. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Green of East-Cambridge, from Acts 17.23. “For as I passed by, and beheld your devotions I found an altar with this inscription TO THE UNKNOWN GOD. Whom therefore ye ignorantly worship, him declare unto you”— Same text morn and afternoon— The Discourses historical—unitarian—Anti-calvinistic— President Quincy proposed that Ward N. Boylston should room with a Son of Oliver Prescott who returns to College after two years absence— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and spent the day with me. Brought to morrow’s Daily Advertiser, containing James Watson Webb’s Manifesto against the re-election of Andrew Jackson— Towards Evening I walked over the Hills with Degrand— Looked at my Walnut, Oak and Ash trees— Oak-leaves singed (with frost?) Very little fruit.— Ash pods, especially. Degrand wants to be employed by the Bank of the United States— Thinks he would make a very good President of the branch—and wishes me to recommend him to N. Biddle— Louisa C. Smith and J. Q. Adams junr dined with us— I read part of Saurin’s Sermon 6. on the unpardonable Sin— Note his argument against Transubstantiation.
27. V. Monday

Henry Wentworth took the place of Simeon Taylor in my Garden— Morning visit from Lieutt. Governor Winthrop, whose appearance indicates beyond the three score years and ten— He declines a re-election, which I told him I regretted— He said he had been long enough Lieutt. Governor— I asked him for some more of his eye-water, which he promised me— A recipe descended from his ancestor the Patriarch John— Frederic Soper was here a Block maker from Cambridge with one eye, one wife and five children— Taken by Danish and French Privateers in 1810—carried to Dantzick. kept nearly two years— Sent to Antwerp—and finally to Bordeaux, whence he came home in 1812. Thinks he has a claim under the Commissions for French indemnities— He was in the Mary and Eliza, Captain Oakington, belonging to John Parker and Son— I advised him first to apply to Mr Parker, and if he could recover nothing through him to send me a statement of facts and I would draw up a Memorial to the Commission for him— I bathed at the wharf—less than 5. minutes in the water, which was cold— Transearthed an Ash-tree and three grape vines up from the seeds in Tumbler and pot. Finished Mackintosh’s Dissertation upon Ethics— excellent—
28. IV. Tuesday

My two wards—Ward Nicholas Boylston and Thomas Boylston, were here this Morning, and I wrote to their Grandmother mentioning the proposal of President Quincy that Ward should room for the ensuing year with Prescott, and requesting that if she consents to this proposition she would so write to Mr Quincy, with whom I promised to confer upon the subject, the day after to-morrow. I have concluded to go then to Cambridge— I received and answered a Letter from a Committee of the AntiMasonic Convention of Plymouth County— And sent to Mrs. Gardiner, her long missing papers— I am still floundering in the mire of Masonry. J. Q. Adams jr brought a Letter to his brother Isaac H. at Westpoint. In the evening I paid a visit to Mr Peter Whitney our Minister—and found his Son George, with his wife still there— Our Ladies also met me there unexpectedly. I began the perusal of my fathers old Journals with a view to resume the biographical sketch of his Life.
29. IV.45. Wednesday— Commencement at Cambridge.

Bathed with Charles and swam about five minutes before dinner— Finished my second Letter to W. L. Stone, upon the entered Apprentice’s Oath in Free-Masonry— Resumed the Biographical sketch of my father’s Life; but found myself at once arrested by the want of assortment of his papers— After dinner I took up with Charles the project of assorting them, and after three hours occupation upon them found we had scarcely begun. I determined to begin by reducing all the Letters to Alphabetical files, and then to subdivide them, into collections from individuals, chronologically arranged— This labour will be exceedingly tedious and long— I was searching for autographs of my father for Mrs White of Florida—and found among them an original draught of Resolutions offered by my father to Congress on the 30th. of September 1774— Luther Spear came and requested me to make my part of the fence at Rock-Island. I promised to meet him down there shortly.
30. IV. Thursday— Cambridge.— Declamations— Φ.Β.Κ.

Went to Cambridge alone in the Carriage— At 9. A.M. in President Quincy’s Study—Boylston prize declamation—4. Juniors 4. Seniors. 2. Graduates—11. Judges—only one first prize awarded to William Whiting a Senior. Three second prizes to H. F. Harrington—Joseph Bennett, and Joseph Harrington— Attended Φ.Β.Κ. Meeting— Chief Justice Lemuel Shaw chosen President— Edward Everett declined— Dr Bradford moved an alteration of rule requiring unanimity for admission. That one black ball shall be taken for accidental, unless a member avows that he put it in— Edward Everett says that is the practice at New Haven; I opposed, and it was indefinitely postponed— C. P. Curtis twice balloted for— Second time admitted— Oration by Jared Sparks. on History. Poem by Felton on Reform— Met Classmates T. M. Harris and G. L. Chandler— Dined at President Quincy’s— Dr Spurzheim there. Judge Story— Mr Ward, Mr Brazer-Storrow, C. P. Curtis and others— Called to see Dr Waterhouse— He and Mrs Waterhouse, promised to come and dine with us next Wednesday— If weather fair— Returned to Quincy this Evening— Dr. Phipps died suddenly this afternoon.
31. IV. Friday. Boston and Quincy—

Mr Joseph Coolidge whom I met yesterday at Cambridge invited me to dine with him this day— I went in the Morning with the Chaise— I met on Neponset Bridge, Judge Hall, one of those whom I had intended to visit— He was alone in a Chaise, and I left Kirke to go in in my Chaise, and went in myself with Mr Hall— He accompanied me to the Council chamber, but they were hearing a Lawyer argue for a commutation of punishment for a man named Roby sentenced to death for murder. The Lieutt. Governor presided and asked me to call again in an hour— I went and passed it with Judge Hall. Then returned to the Council chamber— They were still engaged hearing the Lawyer, but the Lieutt. Governor left them and administered to me the Oaths—three, as a Justice of the Peace throughout the Commonwealth—of which he gave a certificate, on the Commission— I then paid a visit to Mrs Dexter, who was quite unwell— She said she had last Evening asked judge Hall if the Millennium was coming—as H. G. Otis had been out to Quincy to visit me— I called at J. B. Davis’s lodgings but he has been out of the City these three weeks—and at the Tremont House to see Mr. R. D. Shepherd; but he was out. Met in the Streets T. English—George Storer B. W. Crowninshield David Hoffman of Baltimore and Edward Coles sometime Governor of the State of Illinois— After half past one, I could pay no more visits, and went to Charles’s Office where I remained till 3. and read Professor Palfray’s fast day Sermon, of which Judge Hall had given me a copy— Dined with Mr Joseph Coolidge, who resides in the dwelling house built by his father, Governor Lincoln, with his Aid Coll. Josiah Quincy, Mr P. C. Brooks, Edward Coles, Edward Tuckerman, Revd. W. P. Greenwood a Mr Armstrong, and some others were there— I left the table before six, and went immediately to Forbes’s Stable, where I found Kirke with the Horse and Chaise— I was not a little indisposed, but relieved before I came out.— Home before 9— Mr Gibson one of the Sufferers at the railway, the day before I got home from Washington, was here this afternoon— Still suffering the consequences of that accident. Judge Hall could not find the Law, authorising the Governor and Council to appoint persons to qualify civil Officers.
